messages.content: academic advisor
How do I verify if my course substitution requests have been approved?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: The academic system displays substitution status on your degree audit, and notifications are sent via email.
Course Info: Course substitution statuses are viewable on your degree audit.
You can verify your course substitution status by checking your degree audit online. Additionally, look out for any approval notifications in your registered email.
You are an academic advisor.
How many credits do I still need if I've earned 27 credits?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: Audit details show "Credits applied: 27 | Credits required: 36"
Course Info: Degree requirement is 36 credits.
You've earned 27 credits so far, so you'll need an additional 9 credits to graduate.
academic advisor
What should I do if I have incomplete grades in several core courses this semester?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: The academic policy advises that incomplete grades must be resolved within the subsequent semester.
Course Info: Incomplete grades require follow-up action.
If you have incomplete grades, I suggest contacting your instructors right away to arrange a plan for completing the missing work, ideally by the start of the next semester.
academic advisor
Can you explain what additional graduation requirements I must complete beyond earning the required credits?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: The degree audit highlights that apart from credits, students must fulfill thesis/research and administrative requirements such as applying for graduation.
Course Info: Graduation requirements include credit, thesis/research, and administrative steps.

In addition to earning the required credits, you must also complete any thesis or research project requirements, submit the necessary documentation, and apply for graduation. Don't forget to register for your final semester as well.
You are an academic advisor.
Could you provide a brief overview of MIS555?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: The catalog lists MIS555 as a core course emphasizing Business Intelligence.
JSON Excerpts:

{"course": "MIS555 - Business Intelligence and Analytics", "description": "This course introduces business intelligence concepts, including data warehousing, reporting, and visualization, with practical applications in analytics."}
Course Info: Focuses on BI techniques.

MIS555 - Business Intelligence and Analytics is a 3-credit course that introduces you to key business intelligence techniques. You'll learn about data warehousing, reporting, and visualization to help you make data-driven decisions.
You are an academic advisor.
How many credits do I need if I already earned all my required credits?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: Audit indicates "Credits applied: 36 | Credits required: 36"
Course Info: You have met the graduation requirement.
Great news—you've earned all 36 credits required for graduation!
academic advisor
Have I met the graduation requirements related to my thesis track?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: The audit report shows that all thesis and research project requirements are still outstanding, including the oral exam and defense.
PDF Excerpts:
"Thesis and Research Project Requirements: All still marked as 'Still needed'"

Based on your audit, you haven't met the graduation requirements for your thesis track yet. You still need to complete all the thesis requirements, as well as any research project requirements if applicable.
academic advisor
What do I need to have completed to take MIS540 - Cloud Computing for Analytics?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: The catalog notes that CSC544 or an equivalent course is required as a prerequisite for MIS540.
Course Info: Prerequisite: CSC544 (or equivalent) is required.
To take MIS540, you must have completed CSC544 (or an equivalent course) with the minimum required grade.
academic advisor
What is expected for the Draft Thesis submission?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: The audit report indicates that you must submit a Draft Thesis electronically to the Graduate School by the deadline (DRAT).
PDF Excerpts:
"Draft Thesis: Still needed (DRAT)"
You need to submit your Draft Thesis electronically to the Graduate School by the deadline. According to your audit, this step is still pending.
Relevant PDF excerpt: 'If a student fails two or more core classes, they must meet with an advisor to plan a remediation path.'
Cache file excerpt: {"fail_policy":"2 or more core classes failed"}
Required Core Courses:
1) Design and Analysis of Algorithms I (CSC 532)
2) Information Security Management (MIS 534)
3) Network Programming (CSC 544)
4) Software Engineering (CSC 550)
5) Database Management Systems (MIS 555)
6) Analysis, Modeling and Design (MIS 565)
Student: I failed CSC 532 and MIS 555. Can I just retake them next semester?
Advisor:
Since you've failed two core courses, you'll need to meet with an advisor to develop a remediation plan, which may include retaking those courses and additional support.
You are an academic advisor.
How many more credits do I need if I've already earned 33 credits?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: Audit shows "Credits applied: 33 | Credits required: 36"
Course Info: Your degree requires 36 credits.
You've earned 33 credits so far, which means you need just 3 more credits to reach the 36-credit graduation requirement.
academic advisor
Which core courses are mandatory in my first semester as an MSCSIS student?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: New student orientation outlines core course requirements.
JSON Excerpts:
{"core_courses": ["CSC501", "MATH510"]}
Course Info: Mandatory courses include CSC501 and MATH510, among others.
For your first semester, you'll need to register for core courses like CSC501 and MATH510. It's a good idea to double-check the full catalog for any additional requirements.
You are an academic advisor.
How many credits am I short if I've only completed 15 credits?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: Audit report for a new student shows "Credits applied: 15 | Credits required: 36"
Course Info: Total graduation requirement is 36 credits.
You currently have 15 credits, which means you need 21 more credits to meet the graduation requirement.
You are an academic advisor.
Explain CSC550 - Software Engineering in brief.
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: The course catalog for CSC550 outlines a comprehensive software engineering curriculum including project management and risk assessment.

JSON Excerpts: {"course": "CSC550 - Software Engineering", "detail_url": "https://catalogue.uncw.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=74&coid=275991", "description": "Covers the software life cycle, project and risk management, and software reliability techniques.", "Credit Hours": "3"}
Course Info: Two sections available with scheduled meeting times.

CSC550 - Software Engineering is a 3-credit course that introduces you to the complete software development life cycle, including project management and risk assessment. It’s offered in two sections with different meeting times, so be sure to check the schedule for the one that fits best with your plan.
Relevant PDF excerpt: 'Design and Analysis of Algorithms I (CSC 532) is the foundational course recommended to be taken in the first semester.'
Cache file excerpt: {"CSC532_prereq":"None","start_strong":"Yes"}
Required Core Courses:
1) Design and Analysis of Algorithms I (CSC 532)
2) Information Security Management (MIS 534)
3) Network Programming (CSC 544)
4) Software Engineering (CSC 550)
5) Database Management Systems (MIS 555)
6) Analysis, Modeling and Design (MIS 565)
Student: I'm brand new to the program. Which core class should I take first?
Advisor:
Start with CSC 532 (Design and Analysis of Algorithms I) since it serves as the foundation for your entire core curriculum.
You are an academic advisor.
Can you summarize MIS503 for me?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: The catalog defines MIS503 as Programming For Analytics with an emphasis on hands-on programming skills.
JSON Excerpts:
{"course": "MIS503 - Programming For Analytics", "description": "This course introduces programming basics in R and Python tailored for data analytics, including data manipulation and reporting."}
Course Info: Essential programming skills for analytics.

MIS503 - Programming For Analytics is a 3-credit course that equips you with essential programming skills in R and Python, with a strong focus on data manipulation, analysis, and reporting. It’s very hands-on, perfect for getting started in analytics.
Relevant PDF excerpt: 'Some elective courses require completion of at least two core MIS classes, particularly for advanced business-technology modules.'
Cache file excerpt: {"advanced_business_tech":"MIS555 & MIS565 recommended"}
Required Core Courses:
1) Design and Analysis of Algorithms I (CSC 532)
2) Information Security Management (MIS 534)
3) Network Programming (CSC 544)
4) Software Engineering (CSC 550)
5) Database Management Systems (MIS 555)
6) Analysis, Modeling and Design (MIS 565)
Student: I've finished MIS 534 and MIS 555. Which advanced business-tech elective can I take?
Advisor:
With MIS 534 and MIS 555 completed, you can consider an advanced business-technology elective, such as Enterprise Systems Integration.
academic advisor
If I take an elective this semester, will it affect my full-time status?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: Electives are permitted provided the total credit hours remain within full-time limits.
JSON Excerpts:
{"full_time": {"min": 9, "max": 15}}
Course Info: Even with electives, you must maintain between 9 and 15 credit hours.
Taking an elective is perfectly fine as long as your total credit hours remain between 9 and 15. This ensures your full-time status stays secure while allowing you to explore new interests.
academic advisor
Do I need to register for any specific courses to satisfy visa requirements as an international student?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: Visa guidelines require a minimum number of in-person credits.
JSON Excerpts:
{"in_person_requirement": 6}
Course Info: You must complete at least 6 in-person credit hours every semester.
To satisfy your visa requirements as an international student, register for at least 6 credit hours of in-person courses each semester. This is key to staying compliant.
academic advisor
Who is the instructor for CYBR562 - Cybersecurity Strategy and Program Management?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: The course listing for CYBR562 does not provide scheduled meeting times or detailed instructor information.
JSON Excerpts: {"course": "CYBR562 - Cybersecurity Strategy and Program Management", "instructors": "Not available"}
Course Info: No schedule information is available.
Right now, we don’t have any instructor details for CYBR562 - Cybersecurity Strategy and Program Management. Please check the course catalog for the most current updates.
Relevant PDF excerpt: 'Students may replace one core course with an approved advanced course if they demonstrate mastery in that core subject area.'
Cache file excerpt: {"CSC532_alternate":"Advanced Algorithmic Techniques","approval_required":"Yes"}
Required Core Courses:
1) Design and Analysis of Algorithms I (CSC 532)
2) Information Security Management (MIS 534)
3) Network Programming (CSC 544)
4) Software Engineering (CSC 550)
5) Database Management Systems (MIS 555)
6) Analysis, Modeling and Design (MIS 565)
Student: I excelled in a summer algorithms bootcamp. Can I skip CSC 532 and take an advanced course instead?
Advisor:
Yes, you can request to replace CSC 532 with an advanced course, provided you submit evidence demonstrating your mastery in algorithms.
Relevant PDF excerpt: 'Electives are chosen based on career goals: Data Analytics, AI, Project Management, or Cybersecurity.'
Cache file excerpt: {"common_electives":"DataAnalytics, AI, CyberSecurity, PM"}
Required Core Courses:
1) Design and Analysis of Algorithms I (CSC 532)
2) Information Security Management (MIS 534)
3) Network Programming (CSC 544)
4) Software Engineering (CSC 550)
5) Database Management Systems (MIS 555)
6) Analysis, Modeling and Design (MIS 565)
Student: I’ve finished CSC 532, MIS 534, and MIS 555. I’m leaning toward cybersecurity. Which electives fit that?
Advisor:
With your core courses completed, you might consider advanced security electives or a specialized Cybersecurity course that aligns with your interests.
You are an academic advisor.
What are the available time slots for CSC550?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: The advising materials list two distinct CSC550 timings for Fall and Spring.
JSON Excerpts (Schedule): {"CSC550": {"Fall": "Fri 09:00-12:00", "Spring": "Fri 13:00-16:00"}}
Course Info: CSC550 is offered on Friday with different timings by semester.
In Fall, CSC550 is scheduled on Friday from 09:00 to 12:00, and in Spring, it is held on Friday from 13:00 to 16:00.
You are an academic advisor.
Could you describe MIS527 in brief?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: The course outline for MIS527 explains its focus on managing data center resources and infrastructure.
JSON Excerpts:

{"course": "MIS527 - Data Center Management", "description": "This course covers the principles and practices involved in managing a data center, including infrastructure, storage solutions, and virtualization."}
Course Info: Key aspects of data center management.

MIS527 - Data Center Management is a 3-credit course that focuses on the practical aspects of managing a data center, including infrastructure setup, storage, and virtualization. It’s designed to give you a strong grasp of data center operations.
You are an academic advisor.
What is MIS590 about?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: The course description for MIS590 highlights the review of statistics and advanced inferential methods.

JSON Excerpts: {"course": "MIS590 - Research Methods", "detail_url": "https://catalogue.uncw.edu/preview_course.php?catoid=74&coid=276475", "description": "Review of descriptive and inferential statistics along with advanced techniques like multiple regression.", "Credit Hours": "3"}
Course Info: No schedule information available.

MIS590 - Research Methods is a 3-credit course that reviews descriptive and inferential statistics, and also covers advanced techniques like multiple regression. Since there's no schedule available, please check the course catalog link for further details.
You are an academic advisor.
Can you tell me my remaining credits if I've finished my core courses?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: Audit report states "Core credits earned: 18 | Total required: 36"
Course Info: Total degree requirement is 36 credits.
If you've earned 18 core credits, then you need another 18 credits to complete the 36-credit requirement for your degree.
academic advisor
Are there scheduling tips for core classes that are only offered in specific semesters?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: Advising notes highlight that some core courses have limited semester availability.
JSON Excerpts:
{"core_schedule": {"Fall": ["CSC501"], "Spring": ["CSC502"]}}
Course Info: Check the schedule to plan around offerings like CSC501 in Fall and CSC502 in Spring.
Some core courses are offered only during specific semesters. For example, CSC501 might be available in the Fall and CSC502 in the Spring. Planning ahead can really make a difference.
Relevant PDF excerpt: 'Students must maintain a 3.0 GPA in core courses to qualify for departmental scholarships.'
Cache file excerpt: {"scholarship_criteria":"3.0 in core"}
Required Core Courses:
1) Design and Analysis of Algorithms I (CSC 532)
2) Information Security Management (MIS 534)
3) Network Programming (CSC 544)
4) Software Engineering (CSC 550)
5) Database Management Systems (MIS 555)
6) Analysis, Modeling and Design (MIS 565)
Student: My overall GPA is 3.1, but my core courses average to 2.9. Can I apply for the departmental scholarship?
Advisor:
The scholarship requires a 3.0 GPA in your core courses. You might consider retaking or improving a grade in one of your core classes to meet this criterion.
Relevant PDF excerpt: 'All core classes must be finished before enrolling in advanced electives, but one exception allows concurrent enrollment if the student has a GPA above 3.5.'
Cache file excerpt: {"CSC550_prereq":"CSC532","MIS565_prereq":"MIS534"}
Required Core Courses:
1) Design and Analysis of Algorithms I (CSC 532)
2) Information Security Management (MIS 534)
3) Network Programming (CSC 544)
4) Software Engineering (CSC 550)
5) Database Management Systems (MIS 555)
6) Analysis, Modeling and Design (MIS 565)
Student: My GPA is 3.7, and I've completed CSC 532 and MIS 534. Can I take CSC 550 concurrently with an advanced elective?
With your GPA of 3.7, you are eligible to enroll in CSC 550 concurrently with an advanced elective, pending departmental approval.
What is MIS535?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: The course overview states that MIS535 deals with Advanced Data Visualization techniques.
Course Info: Focuses on modern interactive visualization methods.
MIS535 – Advanced Data Visualization is a 3-credit course that teaches modern techniques for creating interactive and insightful data visualizations, enabling effective data storytelling.
Relevant PDF excerpt: 'Students on academic probation must prioritize core courses first.'
Cache file excerpt: {"MIS534_prereq":"None","MIS555_prereq":"Intro to Databases"}
Required Core Courses:
1) Design and Analysis of Algorithms I (CSC 532)
2) Information Security Management (MIS 534)
3) Network Programming (CSC 544)
4) Software Engineering (CSC 550)
5) Database Management Systems (MIS 555)
6) Analysis, Modeling and Design (MIS 565)
Student: I'm on academic probation and have completed CSC 532. Should I take MIS 534 or CSC 544 next?
Since MIS534 has no prerequisites, it would be prudent to take that course next to strengthen your academic record while on probation.
Relevant PDF excerpt: 'Network Programming (CSC 544) requires Intro to Networking as a prerequisite.'
Cache file excerpt: {"CSC544_prereq":"Intro to Networking","CSC550_prereq":"CSC532"}
Required Core Courses:
1) Design and Analysis of Algorithms I (CSC 532)
2) Information Security Management (MIS 534)
3) Network Programming (CSC 544)
4) Software Engineering (CSC 550)
5) Database Management Systems (MIS 555)
6) Analysis, Modeling and Design (MIS 565)
Student: I haven't completed Intro to Networking yet. Which core courses can I start with?
You should begin with courses that do not require Intro to Networking, such as CSC 532 or MIS 534.

Relevant PDF excerpt: 'The thesis requirements include the Comprehensive Oral Exam, Thesis Defense, Draft Thesis, Format Approval Sheet, Final Thesis, Signed Thesis Title Page, and ETD Submission Form, along with graduation application steps.'
Course Info: These components are mandatory before thesis submission.
Student: What are the essential steps I need to complete for my thesis submission?

You must pass your Comprehensive Oral Exam and Thesis Defense, then submit a Draft Thesis with an approved Format Approval Sheet, followed by your Final Thesis with a Signed Thesis Title Page and ETD Submission Form. Additionally, don't forget to apply for graduation and register for your final semester.
academic advisor
Could you confirm the Spring schedule for MIS530 - Cybersecurity for Analytics? I need to plan my evening study sessions.
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: The cache shows MIS530 in Spring is scheduled on Tue/Thu from 14:45 to 16:00.
MIS530 is offered in Spring on Tuesdays and Thursdays from 14:45 to 16:00.
academic advisor
Could you let me know the Fall schedule for CSC502 - Programming Fundamentals? I have an appointment in the early afternoon.
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: The cache indicates CSC502 in Fall meets on Mon/Wed from 13:30 to 14:45.
CSC502 in Fall meets on Mondays and Wednesdays from 13:30 to 14:45.
academic advisor
Can you tell me the Fall schedule for CSC503 - Introduction to Computer Systems? I need to coordinate it with my lab sessions.
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: The cache shows CSC503 in Fall meets on Tue/Thu from 15:15 to 16:30.
CSC503 in Fall meets on Tuesdays and Thursdays from 15:15 to 16:30.
academic advisor
For MIS527 - Data Center Management, is there an option to take it asynchronously in Fall? I require more schedule flexibility.
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: While the cache provides meeting times for in-person sessions, the catalog hints at an online asynchronous option.

MIS527 can be delivered asynchronously online. If the fixed meeting times aren’t provided, it likely means that an asynchronous option is available. I recommend confirming with the department for the most current delivery format.
academic advisor
Regarding MIS535 - Advanced Data Visualization, are there any synchronous sessions, or is it completely self-paced?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: The course catalog suggests that MIS535 materials are provided online with recorded lectures and minimal live sessions.
MIS535 is primarily delivered asynchronously, allowing you to work through the material at your own pace. There may be occasional optional live discussion sessions, but these are not mandatory.
academic advisor
Can you explain the grading breakdown for MIS530 - Cybersecurity Essentials? I'm curious about how projects, quizzes, and the final exam are weighted.
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: The grading rubric for MIS530 details a combination of project work, quizzes, and a final exam.
MIS530’s grading is based on a combination of project assignments, periodic quizzes, and a comprehensive final exam. For the exact weight distribution, please refer to the course syllabus.
academic advisor
I am considering changing my research project to a thesis track. What are the key differences, and what additional requirements would I need to fulfill?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: The program guidelines compare the thesis and research project tracks, highlighting extra documentation and a defense requirement in the thesis track.

Switching to the thesis track involves additional requirements such as a comprehensive oral exam, a formal thesis defense, and extra documentation steps compared to the research project track. I recommend discussing these changes with your department for full details.
academic advisor
Due to a scheduling conflict, I'm exploring the possibility of substituting an elective for a required core course. What options do I have?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json
Relevant PDF: The substitution policy permits replacing a core course with an elective only after departmental approval.

If you have a valid scheduling conflict, you can submit a petition to substitute an elective for a core course. This process requires departmental approval, so please consult your advisor for the formal procedure.
academic advisor
Could you outline the remaining steps I must complete in my thesis process before graduating?
retrieved_data: CACHE_FILE: course_index_cache.json

Relevant PDF: The thesis requirements indicate you must complete a Comprehensive Oral Exam, Thesis Defense, submit a Draft Thesis with a Format Approval Sheet, and then the Final Thesis with a Signed Title Page and ETD Submission Form.

Before you graduate, you must pass your Comprehensive Oral Exam and Thesis Defense, submit your Draft Thesis along with the Format Approval Sheet, and finally submit your Final Thesis with a Signed Title Page and the ETD Submission Form. Also, remember to apply for graduation and enroll in your final semester.
